summary: Robert A. Maheu was a personnel relations executive, former FBI agent, and private investigator who was utilized by the CIA's Office of Security for sensitive assignments starting in the early 1950s. He was involved in various covert operations, including attempts to assassinate Fidel Castro and providing companionship to King Hussein of Jordan. Maheu's background includes employment with the FBI, the Small Business Administration, and his own investigative organization, Robert A. Maheu Associates. He was recruited by the CIA in 1954 and became involved in sensitive assignments. His activities also drew the attention of Senate Subcommittees, raising concerns about potential risks to the Agency. He was investigated by INTERTEL on behalf of the Hughes Tool Company. There are also records of telephone calls made from his office being investigated by the FBI.
significance: Robert A. Maheu's significance in the JFK assassination context stems from his involvement in CIA operations, including assassination plots against Fidel Castro, which could potentially link the CIA to individuals or groups who may have been involved in the assassination of President Kennedy. The documents suggest Maheu was a key figure in covert activities and had connections to individuals of interest to the investigation.
